hobby.message: Still folding origami to stay grounded?
Urban exploration — or just avoiding work?
The city looks different through analog photography, doesn’t it?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think - quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah, still dry. Not much changes. I usually do some, uh, origami at home, keeps my hands busy. Nothing special. Last week I couldn't get paper for a while because of, you know, the service delays.

Dry enough. Been a long week. I fold origami sometimes—little shapes. Makes waiting out delays a bit more tolerable. Actually, the tram breakdown jammed up my routine the other day, had to improvise with scraps.

Still dry. Hasn't rained in a while, but that's not what slows things down lately. I've got this thing for folding origami—just scrap paper, receipts, whatever I can find. Honestly, after I got stuck on the tram last week during that system outage, I passed the time making a few paper flowers. Even gave one away to a kid—she seemed to like it.

Yeah, dry as ever. But the real delays are inside—everything slows these days. I used to look forward to quiet nights making origami, even after long shifts. Last week, during that big BCI glitch, I ended up teaching myself how to fold a kusudama ball using nothing but receipts from my pockets on the tram. Funny way to cope, I guess, when everything outside your control locks up.

Bone dry. And those so-called 'minor disruptions'—feels like we measure days by what the system breaks next, not the weather. You know, I got into origami because folding sharp edges into something simple gave me a sense of order. Last week, stuck on the tram while the BCI froze, I found myself folding every bit of scrap I could scrounge—receipts, a transfer stub. The paper was awful for it, but I managed a little sphere. It's silly, but—when things are unpredictable, I like proving something can still come together. Nobody at work really knows that's how I unwind; it's the only thing that stays purely mine.
hobby_answer: Yeah, folded a few. Nothing special.
Paper’s easier to get than it used to be—if you know where to look.
Can’t really do much when the city keeps stalling public transit, though.
These glitches lately just mean more waiting, less folding, honestly.
Anyway, I stick to small models. Less noticeable that way.
A couple cranes, yeah. Been using receipts more than proper paper.
Kind of hard to find a good spot lately, with all the outages.
Sat on the tram for an hour last week—nothing else to do but fold.
Half the time people stare, like you’re doing something suspicious.
Makes you think twice before bringing out a big piece—especially with everyone on edge.
Mhm, a few cranes. Actually, I folded an orb out of tram receipts the other day.
Transit delays meant we were stuck—gave me time to do something with my hands.
The paper’s not ideal, but you can make do, actually—creases show flaws but also character.
Feels like whenever the system’s off-balance, I end up folding more. Kind of coping, I guess.
People glance, but I don’t mind much—sometimes I even leave the models for someone else to find.
Yeah, and not just cranes—had time for a whole kusudama flower during the last big delay.
When the BCI glitched, everyone froze up, just waiting. I started folding to stay calm.
It’s strange, but folding paper in those tense moments helps me feel a little… outside of things, you know?
Sometimes a kid will watch, or someone asks for one—small kindnesses, when everything else is cold and procedural.
Honestly, these system hiccups force you to find small ways to keep your focus. Origami’s mine.
Definitely—more than usual, in fact. The city’s so on edge, folding is all I can control.
I was stuck during that BCI-induced tram stoppage for ages—used old receipts to make a modular sphere. The paper was awful, but it kept my mind from spiraling.
People looked restless, but seeing someone quietly folding seemed to soften the standoffishness—even gave a flower to a kid, made her smile.

Funny thing—I started origami years back to occupy myself during slow data patches at work. Now, with everything so automated and unpredictable, it’s turned into survival. A way to create order while everything else is up for review.
Feels like everyone’s routines are getting rewritten by algorithms. At least my folding still belongs to me—creases, mistakes, and all.
